Today ward round, - Somkiet admitted 92days for Chronic Osteomyelitis and pathologic farcture of the left femur. - He is on oral Antibiotic and Ranitidin
# today, talked to father about Somkiet's condition that his bone is not healthy and very fragile, it can fracture very easy and he will not be able to walk properly forever, the last option is to do amputation, but now we plan to find out that can we get Orthosis that can help him a little, and to see the Orthopedic who will come on Tuesday 16.2.2016. the father was understand about that problem.
# Today Plan, 1. continue Oral cotrimoxazole and Ranitidin 2. find out the Orthosis 3. to meet Orthopedic Doctor on Tuesday 16.2.2016 4. aim to discharge next week

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs: after a case conference, it was decided that the patient will need to continue treatment with bactrim until beginning of May when a follow-up should be organized with ortho visiting. We need to have a discussion with the patient's father to show him the x-ray and explain that his son will probably never be able to walk on his leg, the bones will be too fragile. We would like them to stay an extra week and have a follow-up beginning of May. We will try to find a way to put an ortheses on is femur. Reviewing the x-ray, we think he has refractured partially his femur when he fell last week.

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs:
#IPD Admission Day 77 for Chronic Osteomyelitis of left tibia and femur -Day 27 post debridement of left tibial necrotic bone fragments. -Also complicated by pathological re-fracture of left distal femur. - Long term complications notable include fusion of left hip and left ankle. On maintenance oral Bactrim post completion of long term IVI Ceftriaxone course (approx 2 months). In rehabilitative phase of admission now mobilizing with PT support and crutches.
Nil recurrence of dyspepsis but not using NSAIDs for analgesia.
On Multivitamin and Iron nutritional support and current\ly receiving good dietary intake.
Heel dressing performed overnight with no clinical concerns for healing ulcer.
Rise in ESR noted to 60. Asymptomatic of pain. No recurrence of fever or symptoms suggestive of recurrence of bone infection.
#Overnight: he did well.no fever,no complain plain,vital sign stable,eating and drinking normal,passing urine and stool normal.
#Plan: 1. Continue mobilization with support 2. Continue nutritional support 3. Continue oral Bactrim

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs:
WFPI XRAY REPORT 25/01/2016:
Chronic osteomyelitis at distal left femur with bony sequestrun in posterior femoral cortical border.
There is pathological femoral fracture and angulation.
It s possible to see possible active bone lesions and sclerosis in distal femoral metaphysis.
There is also possible lesions at left femoral neck?

Plan: meet with family within next week to discuss home environment, need for modifications, and promoting pt self-care and independence in preparation for discharge.

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs:
Findings:
Chronic fracture of the distal femur with mild apex anterior and valgus angulation. Mixed sclerotic/lytic densities in the proximal and distal femoral metadiaphyses including the distal femoral condyle. There may be early physeal closure of the distal femoral physis. Proximal femoral physis not well visualized. At least two regions of ill-defined lucency in the shaft of the femur, concerning for intraosseous abscess.
Mixed sclerotic/lytic densities throughout the tibia, as well as the distal fibula and talus. Long oval lytic lesion in the midshaft of the tibia, concerning for introsseous abscess. The tibia appears laterally offset from the talus, concerning for dislocation at the ankle joint on the AP view. Widened tibiofibular syndesmotic space with destruction of the lateral aspect of the distal tibia. Likely early fusion of the distal tibial physis.
Impression:
1. Changes of likely chronic ostemyelitis throughout the left femur and tibia, as well as the talus and distal fibula. Less likely differential of underlying malignancy (i.e. lymphoma).
2. Multiple lucencies within the diaphyses (2 in the femur, one in the tibia) concerning for intraosseous abscesses.
3. The tibia appears laterally offset from the talus, concerning for ankle joint dislocation. Consider dedicated ankle radiographs to evaluate.
4. Chronic fracture of the distal femur with mild apex anterior and valgus angulation.
5. Suspected early physeal closure in the distal femur and distal tibia.
wfpi x-ray report 21/01/2016

background: Chronic osteomyelitis L tibia, pathological femur fracture. Prev cx with possible H. ducreyii. Surgical debridement 14/12. Intraoperative blood transfusion. Spot Hb 16/12 9.0, 17/12 8.6, confirmed with CBC: hb 8.7 plt 243 wbc 5.2.
progress: IV ceftriaxone& metronidazole. Intraosseous gent to continue. Micro swabs gram stain/culture from 14/12: no organisms seen, pus cells only, culture reported as neg. dressing done today- has pain and pus lateral ankle & upper shin. Needs dressing/review surgeon again tomorrow.
plan: surgeons coming tomorrow *needs ketamine for this as ++pain didnt tolerate today even with 4mg morph. NPO from 6am (surg coming around 10am)

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs: #background: Chronic osteomyelitis L tibia, pathological femur fracture. #progress: Went to OR again today (spinal anaesthesia). returned with lots of fluid, some was irrigation fluid but very dark ??lots of frank blood in 2 separate drains (450mls one bag, 90 mls other bag- we have emptied this evenig so we can keep track of how much ins/outs). fingerprick Hb 10.3 at 7pm 14/12 (pre-op Hb 12.2; operation notes state he had 2 "bags" O+ blood Transfusion intra-operatively but they didnt document actual volume given). Has had quite a bit of pain since returning from OR, so requiring PRN morph. sudden muscle spasms too, diazepam po PRN for 24hrs-48hrs post-op. IV cannula tissued, tried 2x to get new line but not successful. will try again in morning. #plan: Chase microbiology swabs from theatre & from day before. Needs CBC Wednesday 16/12/15 (& if ongoing ++bloody loss in drains then do repeat spot Hb Tuesday). needs new IV line.

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs: 13yo boy day 28 of his admission with pathological fractue femur on background of very longstanding (2yrs) osteomyelitis left leg. Settled last night, no fevers the last few days (iun fact no fevers this admission). Was due for dressing review/change today: has windown cut in plster for reviewing wounds left shin. On taking down dressings today: smelly++, marked purulent ooze from central circular lesion a few cm away from long surgical suture line, also 2 other circular lesions with slight ooze adfjacent to suture line. Has now developed also a new lesion posteriorly, jsut above level of achilles, that is also oozing ++ pus. we have cleaned all wounds, removed soggy parts of cotton lining of plaster adjacent to the wounds, and applied betadeine soaked gazue and fesh cotton lining t these areas. before this we took a few sets of swabs for: gram stain, culture and AFB to send to lab. Dr Cheri aware of wound review & new lesion, photos emailed to her for his records. Somkiet was seen by surgeon & anaesthetist today: they are taking him to theatre tomorrow for next washout, so will be NPO from midnight tonight, has IV fluids charted for this. had pre-op CBC yesterday: Hb 12.2 WBC normal.

encounter.label: Clinical Notes

Wound distal tibia oozingthick purulent on applying pressure. All oozing thick liquid, swabs taken and given to the laboratory for gram stain, AFB and culture Wound lateral malleaous, painful and oozing, area cleaned with N/saline All wounds covered with betadine soaked gauze, layered with gauze and padding and secured with a bandage Anaethatist reviewed patient and for theatre tomorrow. encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs: 13 year old boy with chronic osteomyelitis of L tibia, femur, complicated by pathologic femur fracture. Interval events: Spica cast adjusted by ortho RN, Margo, and bedside RN. Noted purulent oozing from distal drain site. Obtained gram stain of this fluid which showed mixed gram positives and gram negatives. Obtained R leg films which showed good alignment of femur fracture. Bones seem a little stronger, consistent with improved nutrition. Exam: alert, well-appearing, smiling. Distal tibial drain site on my exam had mild oozing, which was mildly purulent. Assessment/Plan: Currently on ceftriaxone which may not be adequately covering organisms causing his osteomyelitis. Could consider ceftazidime to cover pseudomonas, and consider better coverage of staph as well.

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs: Physio: Cast modified by PT and ortho tech Margo with assistance from nursing staff. Pelvic girdle removed and window cut for tibial wound dressing. Proximal drain site healing well, distal drain site oozing creamy brown pus and serous fluid. Wound cleaned by nurse Sing Lao with betadine, dry dressing applied and bandage wrapped. Nursing staff aware. Monitor wound and minimal movement of left leg for now. Continue with right leg and upper body exercises.

13yo boy chronic osteomyelitis left leg and had pathological fracture after last operation currently on IV ceftriaxone (requires this for at least 3weeks IV), has been having ESR/CBC/XR weekly BNO 4days, having lactulose 3 x daily- abdo soft, some fecal loading left side, abdo nontender, will add something more tomorrow if still no BO
this last week having increased purulent dicharge from wound on leg so went back to theatre today for debridement
swabs sent for gram stain before surgery showed: +++ small gram neg bacilli (?suspected haemophilus ducreyi), culture pending
post op today after debridement: mild nausea-given ondansetron 4mg IV they didn't actually put him in a new cast unfortunately-so that needed replacing so we did left femoral nerve block with 12ml lignocaine with short lasting effect, enough to put in new plaster for proper immobilisation of femur
plan: can eat & drink as tolerated encourage oral fluids keep eye on bowels-if no BO tomorrow we will add other laxative continue ceftriaxone BUT increase dose to 100mg/kg/day in 2 divided doses (so for 2g Bd)

Plan: 1. Optimize nutrition ; encourage regular sun exposure to increase vitamin D stores (he's been inside most of time), increase calcium in food. 2. check ESR weekly 3. encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs: PHYSIO: Nov 16/2015. Pt seen for post-op assessment. Left lower extremity immobilized in full leg slab splint. Unable to actively flex L hip. Mild pain at rest to L anterior thigh. Paracetamol received 20 min prior to PT. Breathing well, denies dizziness or fatigue. Sits with assistance, no orthostatic hypotension. Able to stand with crutches and 2 person assist. Attempted ambulation with crutches - stopped as unable to clear ground with L foot - L leg rests on ground in R weightbearing. Returned to bed. Need to clarify if leg can be in dependent position nonWB for ambulation - expat doctor to confirm post-op instructions from ortho surgeon, clarify whether knee must be in full extension or could be re-cast in slight flexion to allow clearance? Bed exercises reviewed, patient demonstrates well. Plan: continue with balloon respiratory exercises and bed exercises for R leg. Introduce upper extremity exercises, await further orders re: ambulation.

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs: PHYSIO: Nov 12/2015 Patient seen for pre-op assessment. 12 month history of chronic osteomyelitis L leg, has been non-weightbearing to both legs with severe deconditioning. Full active ROM of R leg, weakness of quads 3/5 and hamstrings 3/5. Unable to actively flex L knee, minimal flexion passively due to pain and joint restriction. Crutches provided, ambulation attempted with weightbearing on right. 5 steps taken only, returned to bed. Bed exercises given for R knee: extension with knee over pillow (10 second holds x 10), knee extension pushing foot into pillow (30 reps), plantar flexion into pillow (30 reps) - to be done every hour. Pt understands and able to demonstrate exercises. To go for osteotomy Nov 13/2015. Assess post-op.

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs:
Ward Round
Day 3 IPD Admission - Day One Post-Osteotomy for Chronic Osteomyelitis
Overnight, Vomiting food requiring IVI Ondansetron Pain requiring one dose IVI Morphine Rash on both upper limbs (previous problem also)
This morning, A: Own. Talking without difficulty B: Clear lung fields. No respiratory distress C: No signs of missed blood loss. Only 60mL blood through drain overnight. Left toe capillary refill < 2 secs. No sign of compartment syndrome D: Alert E: No other sites of blood loss F: Receiving IVF and drinking oral fluids. Fluid balance from overnight -140mL G: Eating. Not yet opened bowels for two days H: Hb 11.8 last night. Pink in face. Not clinically anemic I: Afebrile. On IV Ceftriaxone 2g daily K: No signs of liver disease L: 1x left hand IVC, IDC M: Multivitamins, Morphine PRN, Paracetamol PRN, Ondansetron PRN, S: No pressure ulcers yet
Problem Summary 1. Not yet opened bowel 2. Rash (diagnosis unknown)
Plan: 1. Stop IVF 2. IDC out then Trial of Void 3. Check formal Hb 4. Continue IV antibiotics (will need 3 weeks total) 5. Sit up 6. Leave drain in (as request by surgeon)

encounter.obs: #Osteomyelitis of L. Leg, Bone death removed at OR Prov.Hosp. #At 6:00PM, Pt return from OR. Pt alert, Drainage blood 250mls, Urine 250mls. Finger Hb 11.6g/dl # Plan, 1. Vital sign q6h x5days, then q12h 2. Dressing change: a) start 2-3days post OP. b) then daily + PRN 3. Leg elevated until swelling down 4. Non-wieght bearing for 6-8weeks 5. Crutches 6.Nutrition 7. Pain Med: Tylenol, NO NSAID! 8. Check CBC days 1,2,3 then weekly; ESR weekly 9. If Ext Fix Pin care with Saline and Chlorox- 2x/day 10. Ambulate when comfortable, start with 5 min. then advance as tolerated 11. Avoid letting left leg lying in a dependent position, Bed rest with leg elevated or Ambulation. Avoid sitting with leg dependent position Wheelchair with leg elevated 12. X-ray Day of Surgery, then at 10days, 3weeks, 6weeks (X-ray Femur/Tibia AP+Lat)

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs:
** A boy 13 y/o admitted 2 day for chronic osteomyeli
*Examination: lung clear, heart normal, abdominal soft. vital sign normal.
*Treatment plan: 1. sent to province hospital.

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs:
Images: Two views of the left femur, two views of the left tib/fib, 2 views of the left ankle
Findings:
Left femur:There is a healed fracture deformity of the distal diaphysis of the femur, with mild apex medial angulation. Sclerosis is present throughout the majority of the femur, extending from the femoral neck inferiorly, relatively sparing the femoral head and greater tuberosity. A more mixed sclerotic and lucent appearance is noted to the distal femur. Mild expansion of the distal femoral metaphysis is present.
Left tibia/fibula: A mixed sclerotic and lucent appearance is noted throughout the diaphysis and both metaphyses of the tibia, relatively sparing the proximal metaphysis. Soft tissues are unremarkable. The fibula appears unaffected.
Left ankle: There is ankylosis at the tibiotalar joint. Bones of the foot are osteopenic. Sclerosis extends into the calcaneus. Remodeling of the talus is demonstrated, with irregularity of the superior aspect.
Impression:
Chronic-appearing changes affected nearly the entire femur and tibia, with ankylosis of the tibiotalar joint, and involvement of the calcaneus. Healed pathologic fracture with angulation of the distal femur. Findings are most consistent with chronic osteomyelitis. Given the relative paucity of periosteal reaction, tuberculosis is a consideration. Chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis could give a similar appearance.
wfpi x-ray report

encounter.label: Clinical Notes
encounter.obs:
13 yr old boy admitted today for chronic osteomyelitis. Child has evidence of bone infection in the left femur and left tibia. He comes to the hospital today for evaluation by the visiting orthopedic surgeon and possible surgery.
Child is unable to sit because of limited joint movement. Chest X-ray today was normal. Sputum was sent for TB testing. One hr ESR was 80; two hour ESR was 95 CBC: WBC 8.7, H/H 13.5/41.9 Plt 427 Bleeding time normal
Plan: Orthopedic surgeon plans exploration of bone and external fixators. Child will have nothing by mouth (NPO) after midnight tonight. Give IV fluid D5NS 80 cc/hr once he is NPO.
